indicators.justification:
Emissions information is available as national open data in Uzbekistan[1],[2]. The data includes the absolute values of emissions (in CO2 equivalent) and total emissions by sector (CO2 equivalent). But some data is not timely and updated. For example, the Data Greenhouse gas emissions in the Republic of Uzbekistan is available by types for the period 2008-2012 only. 
	
On April 19, 2017, at the UN Headquarters in New York, Uzbekistan signed the Paris Agreement. To sign the agreement, a document was submitted to the Secretariat of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change to reduce the national contribution to greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement was ratified on October 3, 2018. In the long run, the Republic of Uzbekistan intends to strengthen measures and measures to combat climate change 2030 - by 2030 to reduce the specific emissions of greenhouse gases by 10% per capita compared to the level of 2010 (GDP)[3].

Sources:

1. Official website of The State Committee of The Republic of Uzbekistan on Statistics. https://stat.uz/en/official-statistics/ecology
2. Open Data Portal Of The Republic of Uzbekistan(official). data.gov.uz
3.https://www.gazeta.uz/oz/2018/10/03/ratifikatsiya/#!

indicators.justification:
National climate vulnerability information is not officially available as open data in Uzbekistan.

Some climate vulnerability information about Uzbekistan is available at the Climate Change Knowledge Portal of the World Bank Group[1].

Uzbekistan is one of the countries at high risk of climate change, according to Gazeta.ru [2], an unofficial website that publishes information about Uzbekistan, citing VMO Secretary-General Petteri Taalas. Since 1880, the average annual temperature in the country has risen by 1.6 degrees Celsius (from 13.2 to 14.8 degrees), which is higher than the average growth rate on the planet. In 2030-2050, the air temperature in the Central Asian region is expected to rise by another 1.5-3 degrees. The largest increase in air temperature is expected here in the Aral Sea region, as specific local climate changes will also occur due to the drying up of the Aral Sea.

Sources:
1. Climate Change Knowledge Portal https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country/uzbekistan/vulnerability
2.https://www.gazeta.uz/ru/2019/09/12/climate-change/

indicators.justification:
Along with the Resolution of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan on measures to ensure transparency of budget information and active participation of citizens in the budget process RP-3917- 22.08.2018 [1], the regulation " On the procedure for posting information on official websites to ensure the transparency of the budget process" was approved[2].
According to the regulations, budget allocators at all levels, local authorities, distributors of state trust funds, and the Executive Board of the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of the Republic of Uzbekistan determine the procedure for posting information on official websites.
With the Charter:
• content and timing of open data to ensure transparency of the budget process;
• forms of information to be posted on official websites;
• Procedures for placing open data have been established to ensure transparency in the budget process.
Currently, the information on the country's budget and expenditures is provided through the "Open Budget" Portal of the Republic of Uzbekistan[3]. However, the data are given in general terms only, no separate accounting processes are provided. It should also be noted that information on some budgets and expenditures is also provided through reports for Budget for citizens and other publications[4].  All information about the budget on this portal are not provided in machine-readable format(s).
According to the relevant amendments to the legislation, the failure to post information on budget transparency on the official websites from April 1 this year is a violation of the procedure for ensuring the transparency of the budget process will result in the imposition of a fine in the amount of twice the calculated amount[5].

indicators.justification:
At a meeting of the Legislative Chamber of Parliament on March 25, 2021, the leaders of political parties reported on the sources of funding for 2020.[1]
According to the chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party of Uzbekistan Akmal Haitov, in 2020 the party received 35 billion 318 million 862 thousand soums[2]. This is the largest number of political parties in 2020.
Of the party's revenues, 29 billion 577 million 131 thousand soums (84%) came from the state budget. The rest came from membership fees, sponsorships and charitable donations, and business activities.
Last year, the People's Democratic Party of Uzbekistan received 23 billion 842 million 410 thousand soums. Of the total funding for the party's activities, 48% was the party's own funds. That's 3 percent more than in 2019.[3]
The Democratic Party "Milliy Tiklanish" received 22 billion 276 million 323 thousand 900 soums in 2020. Of this amount, 20 billion 113 million 494 thousand soums came from the state budget. That's 90% of the total. In 2020, the total cost of the party amounted to 21.6 billion soums[4].
In 2020, the Social Democratic Party "Adolat" received 14 billion 206 million 929 thousand soums. The party spent 13.8 billion soums by the end of the year.[5]

According to the report of the chairman of the Ecological Party of Uzbekistan, the party spent 8 billion 342 million 51 thousand soums last year.[6]
For context, according to the Law on Financing of Political Parties[7], a political party has the right to receive state funding to finance its charter activities, depending on the number of seats in the Legislative Chamber of the Oliy Majlis.

indicators.justification:
It was reported that a video conference chaired by President Shavkat Mirziyoyev was being held on measures to reorganize the system of dealing with public appeals.

It is noted that now, all appeals are conducted in a single electronic database, and the People's Reception receives a quarterly open ranking of government agencies on the handling of appeals.[1]

"By October 1, 2021, a single online platform will be created in all ministries and departments, khokimiyats to register, review and monitor the results of appeals. Through this platform, the activities of ministries and departments, local governments are monitored, and analytical information is submitted to the Senate and the Government on a monthly basis.

indicators.justification:
The current situation in the field of open data in the Republic of Uzbekistan is as follows.
 The Action Strategy[1] for the five priority areas of development of the Republic of Uzbekistan for 2017-2021 has identified new mechanisms for cooperation between government agencies and organizations, citizens, and the business community. In line with the adopted development priorities, the role of public oversight and civil society institutions has been significantly strengthened, with a special focus on improving the transparency and quality of public services through information and communication technologies.
Some measures are being taken in this direction in the country, in particular, the Open Sector of the Republic of Uzbekistan, which in March 2015 will be able to publish socio-economic and socio-political information in various machine-readable formats. The Open Data Portal [2] (hereinafter - portal) has been launched.
The order of formation, placement and processing of open data, the list of open data sets of government agencies and organizations, published by government agencies on their official websites, and the Portal were approved. To date, the Portal has hosted more than 11,000 open data sets from 149 ministries and agencies, and the number of downloads has exceeded 7.5 million[3].
However, despite the work done, several problems limit the development of open data, the publication of which in most government agencies is not a voluntary initiative to improve public life and increase the transparency of government agencies.
The trend is due to some factors, including:
The outdated regulatory and methodological framework that does not meet modern requirements, which leads to shortcomings in the regulation of the Portal;
lack of an effective feedback system that takes into account the views and needs of the population and businesses in the formation and publication of open data;
Limited technical capabilities of the Portal for timely processing and updating of information posted on the Portal;
lack of control system for timely updating of data, ensuring their timeliness, and monitoring the results of public disclosure;
closure of government agencies not only for citizens and businesses but also for other government agencies in interdepartmental electronic cooperation;
these include strict principles for handling personal data that impede the transparency of public authorities.


Sources: 
1. ACTION STRATEGY for the five priority areas of development of the Republic of Uzbekistan in 2017-2021
https://lex.uz/docs/-3107036
2. Open Data Portal of The Republic of Uzbekistan,
https://data.gov.uz
3. The Ministry for Development of Information Technologies and Communications of the Republic of Uzbekistan,
https://mitc.uz/uz/news/view/2687

indicators.justification:
Training courses at the Institute for Staff Advanced Training and Statistical Research [1] can be organized in the form of retraining or advanced training courses, depending on the category of students. The retraining course is designed for employees working in the state statistics system, but whose previous education (higher or secondary special) is not in statistics and economics. In this course, students complete a 576-hour program and at the end of the course defend their dissertation, with successful graduates being awarded a standard diploma. The refresher course is designed for all categories of employees working in government statistics and lasts at least 36 hours. Individuals who are newly hired into the system, but do not have the relevant experience and qualifications, are required to take advanced training courses within one month from the date of employment. In addition, employees transferring to higher organizations within the system must improve their skills in the relevant training courses within the next three months from the date of transfer to the new position. In general, according to the current procedure, every employee working in the system should be covered by advanced training courses at least once every two years. Students who have completed advanced training courses will be issued a certificate in the prescribed form.

Additionally, from March 1 to March 31, 2021, the State Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Statistics[2] organized training sessions on preliminary preparation for conducting multi-indicator cluster surveys. The training was attended by selected supervisors and interviewers from the Republic of Karakalpakstan, the city of Tashkent, and other regions.
The training took place in two stages. At the first stage, the participants were given the concepts of multi-indicator cluster surveys, the structure of the questionnaires, the content and essence of the questions. In the questionnaires, knowledge, and skills were given on the correct, understandable transmission of questions to respondents, and the conduct of surveys.
At the second stage, trial surveys were carried out in the selected mahallas of the Yunusabad district of the capital, Zangiotinsky, and Yangiyul districts of the Tashkent region. Plates were used in trial surveys.
For information: starting from April 5 of this year, the survey process will be collected electronically on tablets in 14,520 households located in 726 selected mahallas in the Republic of Uzbekistan, through personal conversations with respondents in the field.
As a result of the training, about 100 supervisors and interviewers selected from the Republic of Karakalpakstan, the city of Tashkent, and regions were awarded special certificates from the State Statistics Committee and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

indicators.justification:
The Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan, 2012: in accordance with the Resolution of the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan dated September 25, No. 274 "On approval of the Regulations on the Unified State Register of Enterprises and Organizations"[1], the database of the Unified State Register of Enterprises and Organizations is maintained.

Starting from March 4, 2021, the state registration of a new company in Uzbekistan requires the disclosure of its ultimate beneficiary owner (UBO). Government resolution no. 763 dated December 2, 2020 (Resolution 763)[2], has revolutionized the registration procedure that has existed in the country since 2017.

Resolution 763 defines the UBO as an actual owner of the property of a newly created company or an individual who controls an applicant, or whose interests drive money and other property-related transactions. The definition does not set any thresholds or percentages as to the ownership or control over the applicant by a founding individual or entity to identify a UBO. Resolution 763 does not clearly identify the applicant; hence, we presume it refers to a founding individual.

Upon registration, an applicant will be required to disclose the UBO by filling in a questionnaire (to be submitted alongside a standard registration package) electronically. The questionnaire identifies particulars of the UBO of the new company, namely:

full name;
date of birth;
nationality;
residential address;
details of ID;
tax identification number (if relevant); and
contact details (e-mail, phone number).
However, the definition of "company founder" emphasized here may not meet the criteria of beneficial ownership. This does not comprehensively cover ownership as it focuses on "founding individuals".

indicators.justification:
The national Law "On the Rights of Persons with Disabilities" came into force on January 16, 2021.

According to Article 26 of the Law, the state guarantees the exercise of the right of persons with disabilities to information and provides information to persons with disabilities using technologies that are accessible to the general public, in convenient formats, and taking into account various forms of disability.
The state promotes the use of sign language and other alternative forms of communication as a means of communication between people.
The government provides television programs, movies, theater events, and other cultural events in a format that is accessible to people with disabilities. State-run television broadcasts provide audio or subtitles.
The state ensures the publication of fiction, school textbooks, other didactic materials, and teaching aids using alternative forms of communication (Braille and sound forms).
Government agencies and organizations should make it easier for people with disabilities to access the information posted on their official websites and to use the services.
Government agencies and organizations should take into account the convenience criteria for all categories of persons with disabilities in the implementation of public procurement of information and communication equipment and information support for public procurement.
Government agencies and organizations, if necessary, hire a sign language interpreter to provide communication between a representative of that government agency or organization and a person with a hearing impairment.[1]

The introduction of a comprehensive system of data collection, generalization, and accounting allows one to identify current problems, conduct a comprehensive analysis, assess the situation of different groups of people with disabilities, keep a separate account of the availability of facilities for them in infrastructure facilities, improving the system of statistical registration of persons with disabilities, making it possible to cover all areas.[2]

indicators.justification:
The legislative history of data protection in Uzbekistan can be divided into two periods. The first period started with the Law of Uzbekistan of 24 April 1994 No 400-I on Guarantees and Freedom of Access to Information (only available in Uzbek and Russian) ('the Law on Information')[1], and lasted for 16 years, until the enactment of Law of Uzbekistan of 2 July 2019 No. ЗРУ-547 on Personal Data (available in Uzbek, Russian and English)[2] (The Law on Personal Data), which initiated the second period. 
In terms of the Law of Personal Data, it applies to relations arising from the processing and protection of personal data (Article 3 of the Law on Personal Data). The participants in the processing of personal data include the operator of a database and the owner of a database, as well as any representatives or third parties (Article 9 of the Law on Personal Data). An owner and/or operator may be a State body, an individual, or a legal entity (Article 4 of the Law on Personal Data).
The Law on Personal Data does not explicitly define its territorial scope.
The main regulators are the Cabinet of Ministers and the State Personalisation Center ('the SPC') under the Cabinet of Ministers. Several other functions in the sphere of information (data) protection are carried out by the following State bodies:
•	the Ministry for Development of Information Technologies and Communications of the Republic of Uzbekistan ('MITC');
•	the Central Bank of the Republic of Uzbekistan ('the Central Bank');
•	the State Inspection for Control in the Field of Information and Telecommunications of the Republic of Uzbekistan;
•	the Information Agency and the Information Center; and
•	the Interagency Coordination Commission for the improvement of the effectiveness of information activities and data transfer.
The Law on Personal Data does not include any provision that controllers/operators should carry out Data Protection Impact Assessments.
There are no data breach notification requirements under the Law on Personal Data.
The Law on Personal Data does not specifically regulate contractual relations between the owner and the operator.
Notably, data subjects have a statutory duty to provide their personal data in order to protect the foundations of the constitutional order, and for reasons related to morality, health, rights, and the legitimate interests of citizens of Uzbekistan, ensure State defense and security. The subject of personal data has the right to appeal to the authorized state body or court on the protection of his rights and legitimate interests in relation to personal data(Article 30 of the Law on Personal Data).
Persons guilty of violating the legislation on personal data shall be liable in accordance with the established procedure(See: Article 46 of the Code of Administrative Responsibility of the Republic of Uzbekistan[3], Article 141 of the Criminal Code[4]).

indicators.justification:
In 2018, the resolution "On measures to ensure the transparency of budget information and active participation of citizens in the budget process" was adopted[1]. From 2020, the state budget and the budgets of state trust funds will be approved by a law prepared in accordance with advanced international standards, with detailed information. The information portal "Open Budget" has been launched[2]. The strategy "Digital Uzbekistan - 2030" was approved[3].

The Decree of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan "On additional measures to ensure the transparency of government agencies and organizations, as well as the effective implementation of public control" [4] has become an important legal basis for the consistent continuation of work in this area. On the basis of this decree, new and effective practices are being introduced to address many pressing issues in the field.

Take, for example, the much-discussed public procurement sector. It is true that in recent years, government agencies and organizations have been posting statistics on the Open Data Portal online [5]. However, much remains to be done to ensure full transparency in public procurement.
Another important issue: it is known that the heads and employees of a number of government agencies are members of the supervisory boards of commercial organizations. However, there is no public information about this in Uzbekistan. Such information is now intended to be disclosed and conflicts of interest are to be avoided.

4. https://lex.uz/docs/-5459107

indicators.justification:
According to RESOLUTION OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN ON MEASURES TO ENSURE TRANSPARENCY OF BUDGET INFORMATION AND ACTIVE PARTICIPATION OF CITIZENS IN THE BUDGET PROCESS.RP-3917- 22.08.2018 [1], from 2019, citizens can participate in the distribution of budget funds. At least 10% of the additional resources of the district (city) budgets are used to finance activities formed on the basis of public opinion.
The budgets of the state budget and state trust funds, the main directions of tax and budget policy, as well as reports on budget execution are subject to mandatory public discussion before they are submitted to the Legislative Chamber.
Along with the projects and reports, the information publication "Budget for Citizens", developed by the Ministry of Finance, is published for public discussion[2].
It is also mandatory to publish the conclusions of the Chamber of Accounts on the results of external audits and evaluations of the draft budgets, tax, and fiscal policy guidelines, along with the annual report on their implementation.
The OPEN BUDGET portal, which was launched in 2019, is publishing draft budgets, reports on their implementation, and the conclusions of the Accounts Chamber. Information on activities that are proposed to be funded from additional sources to form a public opinion is also be posted here.

indicators.justification:
From May 22 to June 6 2021, on the portal of discussion of draft regulations of the Republic of Uzbekistan[1], the draft law "On public civil service" was submitted for public discussion.
It was noted that the draft law is designed to create a legal framework for regulating relations in the field of civil service.

Article 3 of the draft law defines the application of this law to all civil servants of the Republic of Uzbekistan, except for the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, deputies of the Legislative Chamber and members of the Senate of the Oliy Majlis, the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Uzbekistan, the Ombudsman, the Jo'qorg'i Kengesi of the Republic of Karakalpakstan and representative bodies of state power and for judges.
According to global experience, the officials listed above fall into the category of political servants, not civil servants.

Article 18. Declaration of income, property, and large expanses of civil servants and their families.

Every year, civil servants are required to file a declaration of income, property, and a large number of expenses for themselves and their family members in the manner prescribed by law.

The list established by the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan may establish additional requirements for the declaration of income, property, and a large number of expenses of certain categories of civil servants, including an extended range of their close relatives.

Candidates for civil service must submit a declaration of income, property, and large expanses of themselves and their family members at the time of employment in the civil service. Information on the submission of the declaration is checked by the personnel department before the candidate enters the civil service.

Article 59 Grounds for termination of public civil service.

Failure to submit a declaration of income, property, and large expenses of a civil servant and family members, violation of the deadlines for submission of intentional submission of incomplete or incorrect information is one of the grounds for termination of the Civil Service.

Deputy Minister of Justice Bahrom Kuchkarov[2] explained why the draft law "On Civil Service" provides for exceptions for officials. The legal status of governors is determined by the Constitution of the Republic of Uzbekistan, the Constitution of the Republic of Karakalpakstan, and other laws, so the law "On Civil Service" is applicable to parts not previously regulated by law.
 He also noted that the draft declaration partially covers the issue of declaration and does not provide a declaration procedure, because it is a separate procedure, a separate process. It applies to everyone, so it is the same thing. This is a separate element of the anti-corruption system. It is therefore partially reflected here.

 Sources:
1. The portal of discussion of draft regulations of the Republic of Uzbekistan, https://regulation.gov.uz/uz/document/18047

2. Unofficial online news publication.
https://kun.uz/uz/news/2020/06/11/davlat-fuqarolik-xizmati-togrisidagi-qonun-loyihasida-nima-uchun-mansabdorlarga-istisnolar-belgilanganiga-izoh-berildi

indicators.justification:
In Uzbekistan, there are 5 formal parties and 4 Public associations[1]:

Formal parties
1.People's Democratic Party of Uzbekistan
2.UZLiDeP / Liberal Democratic Party of Uzbekistan
3.UzDP / Democratic Party of National Revival of Uzbekistan
4.SDP Adolat / Social Democratic Party of Uzbekistan Adolat
5.Ecoparty / Ecological Party of Uzbekistan

Public associations
1.Youth Union of Uzbekistan
2.Uzbekistan Youth Future Foundation
3.Uzbek Center for Spirituality and Enlightenment
4.National Movement for the Rise of Uzbekistan

Political parties have the right to nominate a candidate for the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, a candidate for the Legislative Chamber, and a candidate for local councils[2].

Political parties and their organizations are prohibited from having bank accounts with more than one bank, as well as accounts in foreign banks(Article 6, Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Financing of Political Parties)[3].

Political parties have to report on their election campaign finances.

"A political party must annually submit financial reports on financial and other funds received and spent during the reporting period to the financial authorities, state tax service, the Accounts Chamber and the Ministry of Justice of the Republic of Uzbekistan within the timeframe and in the manner prescribed by law.
A political party shall submit to the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Uzbekistan an interim report on the day of elections on the state funds allocated to it to finance its participation in the elections, and after the announcement of the election results ";

The financial report of a political party must contain information on the sources and amounts of funds received during the reporting period, the expenditure of these funds, the value of the property of the political party, as well as the state registration of the party.

If charitable assistance is received from legal entities and citizens of the Republic of Uzbekistan in other forms, the political party shall evaluate it in monetary terms in accordance with the legislation of the Republic of Uzbekistan and include relevant information, including information on the charitable donor in the financial party's financial statements.

The financial report of a political party contains the receipt and expenditure of public funds in a separate section. 

In this case, the funds spent by a political party to participate in the election shall be taken into account separately.

The form of the report on financing the participation of a political party in the elections and the deadline for its submission shall be determined by the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Uzbekistan.

The reports of the political party will be published on its official website and in print(Article 16, Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Financing of Political Parties)[3].

Leaders of political parties reported on the financing of the party's activities in 2020 and its sources. The UzLiDeP party received 35.3 billion soums, which is the largest amount transferred to the parties. The main sources of funding for the National Revival and UzLiDeP parties were the state budget. 48% of the PDP's expenses are covered by its own funds[4].

According to the interim report[5] of OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights in 2019, The legislation on the registration of political parties – which ODIHR had assessed as burdensome and open to arbitrary application – remains largely unchanged. The only registered parties are those represented in parliament. With the exception of the Ecological Party of Uzbekistan (EPU), no new party has been registered since 2003 (with the exception of the DPU – Milliy Tiklanish, which was established through a merger of Milliy Tiklanish and the National Democratic Party Fidokorlar, in 2008.) According to the Ministry of Justice, no applications have been received either. 
 

Sources:

1.https://uz.wikipedia.org/wiki/O%CA%BBzbekiston_siyosiy_partiyalari
2.ELECTION CODE OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN. https://lex.uz/acts/-4386848
3.Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan on Financing of Political Parties, 2004.  https://www.lex.uz/docs/168391
4.https://www.gazeta.uz/oz/2021/03/27/party/
5.https://www.osce.org/files/f/documents/8/1/442093.pdf

indicators.justification:
It is known that the Resolution of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan dated July 4, 2018 "On measures to organize the activities of public councils under government agencies"[1] defined the main tasks, functions, powers, and procedures for organizing public councils under government agencies. According to it, the public council was established by the decision of the head of the state body; the council conducts its work on a public basis and is a permanent advisory body, the decisions of which are of a recommendatory nature.
However, 1.5 years have passed since then, and the activities of public councils established under government agencies are not organized at the level of today's requirements. The results of monitoring and analysis conducted by the Center for Development Strategy show that such public works are often organized only on paper for the sake of formality, and their place and role in real life are almost invisible.
The results of the study conducted by the Center for Development Strategy show that the use of these forms of public control and the achievement of concrete results are unsatisfactory. In particular, norms such as public hearings, public monitoring, public expertise are almost not implemented. Additionally, the practice of hearing reports of executive authorities, other organizations, and institutions by mahalla citizens' assemblies has not yet been established[2].

Sources:
1.RESOLUTION OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN ON MEASURES TO ORGANIZE THE ACTIVITIES OF PUBLIC COUNCILS UNDER STATE BODIES.RP-3837.04.07.2018
https://lex.uz/docs/3808838
2.https://strategy.uz/index.php?news=799

indicators.justification:
The Constitution of the Republic of Uzbekistan [1] and the Law "On the Principles and Guarantees of Freedom of Information" [2] protect the right of citizens to freely and without hindrance seek, receive, disseminate, and use any information. In particular, according to Article 29 of the Constitution, everyone has the right to freedom of thought, speech, and religion. Everyone has the right to seek, receive and impart information of their choice. According to Article 43 of the Constitution, the state guarantees the rights and freedoms of citizens enshrined in the Constitution and laws.

According to Article 8 of the law, the state protects the right of everyone to seek, receive, inspect, disseminate, use, and store information. According to Article 16, those guilty of violating the law on the principles and guarantees of freedom of information shall be held liable in accordance with the established procedure.

What liability does the legislation define?

There are a number of legal measures that can be taken against those who oppose the search, acquisition, and dissemination of information. In particular, the Criminal Code of the Republic of Uzbekistan [3] provides for intimidation with violence (Article 112), endangerment (Article 117), insult (Article 140), abuse of power or position. (Article 205), deviation from the scope of authority or career (Article 206), indifference to the position (Article 207), the inaction of the authorities (Article 208). Depending on the details of the case, those responsible can be prosecuted under several of the above articles.


 Sources:
1. THE CONSTITUTION OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN. https://lex.uz/docs/4032775
2. LAW OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN ON GUARANTEES AND FREEDOM OF RECEIPT OF INFORMATION
400-I 24.04.1997
https://lex.uz/docs/-1319
3. CRIMINAL CODE OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN.
https://lex.uz/docs/111453

indicators.justification:
The special information portal on public procurement has been officially launched at xarid.uz[1]. All public procurement announcements and their results are now posted on the portal, and public procurement is conducted in the form of e-shops and e-auctions aimed at reducing the starting price. This, in turn, may ensure the openness and transparency of public procurement.

There are a number of shortcomings in public procurement data and related cases, and some cases of public procurement have been widely discussed on social media and in the media.[2],[3],[4]. 


"The Code of Administrative Responsibility of the Republic of Uzbekistan establishes liability for violation of the legislation on public procurement. According to it, officials who do not place the public procurement plan, announcements for public procurement on a special portal will be fined from ten to fifteen times the basic calculation amount"-said Aktam HAITOV-Leader of the UzLiDeP faction[5].
